title: Gavin and Stacey star's heartbreak watching mum dying of cancer in geriatric ward
text:

Alison Steadman watched helplessly as her mother lay dying from pancreatic cancer on an understaffed ward.

It was one of the most painful experiences of the actress’s life and inspired her to be­­­come the voice of a powerful new documentary which investigates how the NHS is being dismantled.

The Gavin & Stacey star doesn’t point the finger at any of the hard-working staff for her mother’s plight but lays the blame firmly at the door of successive Tory governments who have bled the service dry.

Of mum Marjorie she says: “The worst thing was, because she was 80, she was put in a geriatric ward.

“The hospital was underfunded, understaffed and under pressure.

“Patients were literally ignored. It was heartbreaking.

“She was very ill and she felt sick all the time. She was dying of cancer.

“I kept going up to the desk and asking them to go and help her.

“It had been an hour and nobody had come round. It broke my heart.”

(Image: Philip Coburn/Daily Mirror)

Marjorie, who was diagnosed in 1994 and died two years later aged 82, spent a week on the “chaotic” NHS ward in Liverpool where Alison also saw other patients suffering.

She says the few staff were so overworked she found herself having to help other vulnerable patients.

“They didn’t have any staff. You didn’t get medication until the trolley came round at certain times.

“You only got attention for food and there was nobody to help feed them.

"It was a nightmare. There was a lady brought in and she’d had a stroke. It was the saddest thing. This woman had false teeth and she had glasses.

“Because it had been an emergency she’d forgotten to bring them with her.

“So this poor woman couldn’t eat. She couldn’t chew. She could only make sounds. She couldn’t see properly. She had no family.

“She was just sitting in this bed. They came round and gave her tablets, just plonked them on the table next to her, she didn’t even have any water to swallow them with. I had to go over to help feed her. It simply broke your heart.”

Alison, 73, is grateful her mum was eventually moved to a Marie Curie hospice, of which she is an ambassador, instead of staying on the ward.

But she knows not everyone is as fortunate.

“I feel very passionately about the fact we’re losing our NHS,” says Alison, who grew up in Childwall, Liverpool.

“There’s no way people can say we’re not because we are. It’s a very slow gradual process.

“The core of the problem is the private sector creeping in more and more. It started quite a long time ago and it’s ruining Nye Bevan’s wonderful creation.

“ Boris Johnson needs to sit down and watch something like this film – though he never would.”

More than 60 contributors – politicians and leading medics – were interviewed for the documentary Under The Knife which next week begins a series of free screenings around the country.

Those featured include former PM Tony Blair , Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell, Lord Owen, Gina Miller and Michael Mansfield QC.

(Image: Philip Coburn/Daily Mirror)

Says Alison: “I’m only an observer. The woman who made this film, producer Pam Kleinot, she was seeing things changing over the years and how they were failing when she worked in the health service.

“This film is what we need to highlight all the problems.

“I had private healthcare for years as a back-up. I’ve got rid of it now because I realise that is undermining our health service. They are just making money, they’re not caring for us.”

The film, supported by campaign group Keep Our NHS Public, also touches on how our NHS will be at the mercy of the American firms after Brexit , particularly if we leave the EU without a deal.

Alison, who voted Remain, is angry at the state of the UK in the aftermath of the referendum... and angry at what it means for the NHS.

She says: “The private companies who make drugs will try and keep it to the maximum price so they can make trillions.

“Everyone who has the illness needs the drug but the company are making so much money. This is the reality of what we’re facing.

“We need a system that is away from profit-making and is focused on giving people proper care, where everyone is equal and entitled to this care.

“I just think our country is a total mess. I am embarrassed to be British.

“The rest of Europe and the world is looking at us going ‘What are they doing?’

“Since we joined the EU I’ve loved being European, being part of Europe.With the history we’ve got, after the Second World War, here we are all united.

“It makes me so sad. We should want to work towards being united, not divided.”

Politics aside, it’s been an extremely busy year for Alison.

Today she’s nipped back home to North London, where she lives with partner Michael Elwyn, for just one night before returning to Manchester to carry on filming for a new BBC series, Life, written by Doctor Foster writer Mike Bartlett.

And she recently finished filming for the Gavin & Stacey Christmas special, where she will revive the role of Pam Shipman to the delight of fans.

“Pam is so special to me,” she says, beaming.

“From when I read the first script I just thought ‘This is really good’.

“I always know straight away if it’s something I want to do.

“I can hear it in my head when I read it. And I could hear Pam straight away. But we were all 100% convinced it would never happen. I always used to say leave well alone. But then, suddenly, I got this message from Ruth Jones.

“It said ‘Would you consider doing a Christmas special?’ I was like ‘What!’ I just couldn’t believe it.

“We were all a bit hysterical, hugging, kissing, laughing, crying.

“We had two or three days round the table having Christmas dinner .

“There was a lot of banter going on, a lot of gags, particularly from Rob Brydon. I hope people do like it. The thing about it, and what I’ve always felt about Gavin & Stacey, is that there’s warmth there.

“They might row, they might get upset, but you know underneath it all they love each other.”

As for her own life, the star says she won’t be giving up acting any time soon although she admits she has had to slow down in recent years.

“I still have to travel a lot for work but I am still healthy – touch wood,” she laughs as she knocks on the table.

“It’s the old actors’ thing, you’re either in the money or out of it.

“And oh, how I love it. I’d never want to give up, however long I’ve got left.

“Though I do get tired now, learning lines is a chore.

“I used to be able to do it in an hour but now I need a break.

“But I still feel very lucky and privileged to be doing what I am doing.”

(Image: David Dyson)

Only Labour can restore national treasure's health

By Ken Loach, Bafta Award-winning film director

It’s a hugely important film because it explains why the NHS is on its knees.

The danger is not only insufficient funding but we need to remove all the private contractors, which are in effect privatising it.

We’ve got to get back to the original principles, because it’s the most efficient.

There’s a moral question too – why should big corporations make money out of our healthcare and looking after our children? Does Richard Branson need another island in the West Indies?

No, he doesn’t.

We need proper funding and proper public ownership of it again, where everyone has a direct contract from the health service, from caterers to cleaners to consultants.

We do not want a system like America. We know it’s massively unequal. It’s massively inefficient and gives massive profits to a few people.

That’s the opposite of what Nye Bevan’s dream was and we’ve got to make that dream a reality again.

The election coming up is critical. People have got to get out and vote Labour – that way, we can restore the National Health Service.

If we don’t win, we shall lose it.
description: EXCLUSIVE: Gavin and Stacey actress Alison Steadman says we are losing our NHS as she spoke out about her heartbreak at watching her mum die in an underfunded, understaffed NHS hospital
